questions.question: Under Section 469, a passive activity is generally defined as:

options.B: A trade or business in which the taxpayer does not materially participate
options.C: Any activity that generates portfolio income

questions.explanation: A passive activity is a trade or business in which the taxpayer does not materially participate, or a rental activity (with certain exceptions). Portfolio income (interest, dividends) is not passive activity income.
questions.tip: Passive = trade/business without material participation OR rental activity.

questions.question: The most commonly used material participation test requires participation of more than:

options.B: 250 hours per year
options.C: 500 hours per year

questions.explanation: The most straightforward material participation test requires more than 500 hours of participation in the activity during the tax year. There are seven tests, but 500 hours is most commonly used.
questions.tip: 500+ hours = material participation (primary test). Other tests exist for complex situations.

questions.question: An individual who actively participates in a rental real estate activity may deduct up to what amount of passive rental losses against nonpassive income?
questions.explanation: Individuals who actively participate in rental real estate may deduct up to $25,000 of passive rental losses against nonpassive income. This allowance phases out between $100,000 and $150,000 of modified AGI.
questions.tip: $25K rental loss allowance with active participation; phases out at $100K-$150K MAGI.

questions.question: Passive activity losses can generally be deducted against:

options.B: Passive activity income only
options.C: Portfolio income and passive income

questions.explanation: Passive activity losses can only be deducted against passive activity income. They cannot offset active income (wages, business income with material participation) or portfolio income (interest, dividends).
questions.tip: Passive losses = passive income only. Cannot offset wages or portfolio income.

questions.question: When a taxpayer fully disposes of a passive activity in a taxable transaction, what happens to suspended passive losses?

options.B: They continue to be limited to passive income
options.C: They become fully deductible against any income

questions.explanation: Upon complete disposition in a fully taxable transaction, all suspended passive losses from that activity become deductible against any income (active, passive, or portfolio). This is the primary 'release valve' for trapped losses.
questions.tip: Full disposition = suspended losses released against all income types.

questions.question: To qualify as a real estate professional, a taxpayer must spend what percentage of their personal services in real property trades or businesses?

options.B: More than 50%
options.C: More than 75%

questions.explanation: To be a real estate professional, more than 50% of personal services performed during the year must be in real property trades or businesses in which the taxpayer materially participates, AND total hours must exceed 750.
questions.tip: REP test: >50% of services + >750 hours in real property businesses.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the seven material participation tests?

options.A: Participation for more than 500 hours during the year
options.B: Participation constitutes substantially all participation in the activity
options.C: Participation for more than 100 hours if no one else participates more
options.D: Ownership of more than 50% of the activity

questions.explanation: Ownership percentage is not a material participation test. The seven tests focus on participation hours, not ownership. One can own 100% of an activity and still be passive if participation is insufficient.
questions.tip: Material participation = hours and involvement, not ownership percentage.

questions.question: A taxpayer owns three businesses and wants to group them as a single activity for passive loss purposes. Which factor is NOT relevant to grouping?

options.B: Common management
options.C: Geographic location

questions.explanation: Grouping is based on appropriate economic units considering common ownership, management, location, and business type/interdependence. Personal wealth is irrelevant to whether activities constitute an appropriate economic unit.
questions.tip: Grouping factors: ownership, management, location, business interdependence—not personal wealth.

questions.question: What is the primary difference between 'active participation' and 'material participation' for rental real estate?

options.B: Active participation is a lower standard that allows the $25,000 allowance
options.C: Material participation applies only to commercial property
options.D: There is no difference—the terms are interchangeable

questions.explanation: Active participation is a lower standard requiring only meaningful involvement in management decisions (approving tenants, terms, repairs). Material participation requires meeting one of seven tests (typically 500+ hours). Active participation enables the $25,000 allowance.
questions.tip: Active < Material. Active = meaningful involvement for $25K allowance. Material = 500+ hours.

questions.question: A married taxpayer filing jointly has modified AGI of $125,000 and $20,000 of rental losses with active participation. What amount is deductible against nonpassive income?
questions.explanation: The $25,000 allowance phases out by 50% of MAGI over $100,000. Phase-out: ($125,000 - $100,000) × 50% = $12,500 reduction. Remaining allowance: $25,000 - $12,500 = $12,500. Since losses are $20,000, only $12,500 is deductible.
questions.tip: Phase-out: $25K - (50% × (MAGI - $100K)). Fully phased out at $150K MAGI.

questions.question: A taxpayer has $50,000 of passive losses but only $30,000 at risk in the activity. What is the ordering of loss limitations?

options.B: At-risk limits first, then passive
options.C: Both limits apply simultaneously
options.D: Taxpayer chooses which limit applies first

questions.explanation: The at-risk rules (Section 465) apply before the passive activity rules (Section 469). First, losses are limited to the at-risk amount ($30,000). Then passive rules further limit deductibility of the $30,000 against nonpassive income.
questions.tip: Loss limitation order: At-risk (465) → Passive (469) → Excess business loss (461).

questions.question: A taxpayer works 800 hours in rental real estate activities and 1,000 hours in a W-2 job. Does the taxpayer qualify as a real estate professional?

options.B: No—real estate hours don't exceed 50% of total services
options.C: Yes—if material participation is met in real estate
options.D: No—W-2 employees cannot be real estate professionals

questions.explanation: The taxpayer fails the >50% test: 800 hours is only 44% of total services (800 + 1,000 = 1,800 hours). Both tests must be met: >750 hours AND >50% of services. W-2 employees can qualify but often struggle with the 50% test.
questions.tip: REP requires BOTH >750 hours AND >50% of all services. Both must be met.

questions.question: A taxpayer owns a building personally and rents it to their S corporation in which they materially participate. The rental income is treated as:

options.A: Passive income that can absorb passive losses
options.B: Nonpassive income under the self-rental rule
options.C: Portfolio income

questions.explanation: Under the self-rental rule, rental income from property rented to a trade or business in which the taxpayer materially participates is recharacterized as nonpassive. This prevents using passive rental income to absorb other passive losses.
questions.tip: Self-rental income = nonpassive if rented to business with material participation.

questions.question: A limited partner can satisfy material participation only through which tests?

options.B: The 500-hour test, the facts and circumstances test, or five-of-ten-years test
options.C: Only the 500-hour test
options.D: Limited partners can never materially participate

questions.explanation: Limited partners can only use three of the seven material participation tests: (1) 500+ hours, (2) material participation in 5 of prior 10 years, or (3) personal service activity with material participation in any 3 prior years. The 100-hour test and others are unavailable.
questions.tip: Limited partners: Only 500-hour, 5-of-10 years, or 3-year personal service tests apply.

questions.question: Rental activity is NOT automatically treated as passive if the average rental period is:

options.B: 30 days or less
options.C: 7 days or less

questions.explanation: Rentals with an average period of 7 days or less are not automatically passive (e.g., hotel operations). If significant personal services are provided, rentals averaging 30 days or less also escape automatic passive treatment.
questions.tip: ≤7 days average rental = not automatically passive. Consider material participation.

questions.question: A taxpayer sells a passive activity using an installment sale. When are suspended losses released?

options.A: Entirely in the year of sale
options.B: Pro rata as installment payments are received
options.C: Not until all payments are received
options.D: Suspended losses are forfeited in installment sales

questions.explanation: When a passive activity is sold on installment, suspended losses are released proportionately as gain is recognized. Each year, losses equal to the gain recognized (gross profit ratio × payments) become deductible.
questions.tip: Installment sale: Suspended losses released pro rata with gain recognition.

questions.question: A taxpayer has two activities: one profitable and one generating losses. When is grouping most beneficial for passive loss utilization?

options.B: When the profitable activity is nonpassive and loss activity is passive
options.C: When grouped to achieve material participation in the combined activity
options.D: Grouping is never beneficial for losses

questions.explanation: Strategic grouping can help achieve material participation when hours in individual activities are insufficient but combined hours exceed 500. This converts activities from passive to nonpassive, allowing loss deduction.
questions.tip: Group activities to aggregate hours for material participation. Plan carefully—generally irrevocable.

questions.question: A taxpayer has three significant participation activities with 150, 200, and 175 hours respectively. The combined activity income is $30,000. How is this income treated?

options.B: All nonpassive income due to combined hours exceeding 500
options.C: Recharacterized as nonpassive to the extent of passive losses from other activities

questions.explanation: Income from significant participation activities (100+ hours but not material participation) is recharacterized from passive to nonpassive to the extent of other passive losses. This limits 'PAL stacking' strategies.
questions.tip: SPA income recharacterization: Passive income becomes nonpassive to offset passive losses.

questions.question: A taxpayer contributes $50,000 cash and borrows $100,000 (personally guaranteed) to invest in a rental property. What is the at-risk amount?
questions.explanation: At-risk includes cash contributed plus amounts borrowed for which the taxpayer is personally liable (recourse debt). Here: $50,000 + $100,000 = $150,000 at risk. Nonrecourse debt is generally not at-risk, with an exception for qualified real estate financing.
questions.tip: At-risk = cash + recourse debt. Qualified nonrecourse real estate debt also counts.

questions.conceptTested: REP election to treat as single activity
questions.question: A real estate professional owns five rental properties. Without an election, how many activities must material participation be determined for?

options.B: Five separate activities
options.C: Depends on grouping choices
options.D: Material participation is automatic for REPs

questions.explanation: Without the election under Reg. 1.469-9(g), each rental property is a separate activity requiring separate material participation. REPs often elect to treat all rentals as one activity to meet the 500-hour test more easily.
questions.tip: REPs should usually elect single-activity treatment for rentals. Otherwise, 500 hours per property!

questions.question: A taxpayer gifts a passive activity with $100,000 of suspended losses to their child. What happens to the suspended losses?

options.B: Losses are released and deductible by the donor
options.C: Losses are added to the property's basis

questions.explanation: When a passive activity is gifted, suspended losses are added to the donee's basis in the property rather than being released. This differs from a sale, where losses are fully deductible, or death, where losses are lost.
questions.tip: Gift of passive activity: Suspended losses → donee's basis. No current deduction.

questions.question: Passive activity credits (such as rehabilitation credits from passive activities) can offset tax on:

options.B: Passive activity income only (with equivalent tax)
options.C: Active income if material participation is achieved

questions.explanation: Passive activity credits can only offset tax attributable to passive income, similar to passive losses. The credit is computed as tax on net passive income. Excess credits are suspended and carried forward.
questions.tip: Passive credits = offset tax on passive income only. Same limitation concept as losses.

questions.question: Passive activity income is subject to the 3.8% net investment income tax (NIIT). A real estate professional's rental income is:

options.B: Exempt from NIIT if derived in ordinary course of a real property trade or business
options.C: Subject to NIIT only if MAGI exceeds $250,000

questions.explanation: REP rental income may be exempt from NIIT if derived in the ordinary course of a trade or business. This requires material participation and REP status. Without REP status, rental income is generally net investment income.
questions.tip: REP + material participation = potential NIIT exemption for rental income.

questions.question: For passive activity purposes, determining what constitutes a single 'activity' is based on:

options.A: Each legal entity is one activity
options.B: Facts and circumstances using appropriate economic unit factors
options.C: Each separately identified business on Schedule C

questions.explanation: Activities are determined based on facts and circumstances using appropriate economic unit factors: common control, common ownership, geographic location, and business interdependencies. Multiple businesses can be one activity, or one business can be multiple activities.
questions.tip: Activity definition is flexible based on economic factors, not just entity structure.

questions.question: The low-income housing credit (LIHTC) has a special rule regarding passive activity limitations. This rule allows:

options.B: Offset of up to $25,000 of regular tax from non-passive income
options.C: Exemption from passive credit rules entirely

questions.explanation: LIHTC benefits from a special $25,000 equivalent allowance similar to the rental loss allowance. This allows the credit to offset tax on non-passive income up to the equivalent of $25,000 of deductions, subject to phase-out.
questions.tip: LIHTC: Special $25K equivalent allowance for passive credit offset.

questions.question: A working interest in an oil and gas property held directly (not through a limited partnership) is:

options.B: Never passive, regardless of participation
options.C: Passive unless material participation is met
options.D: Passive only if the taxpayer is a limited partner

questions.explanation: A working interest in oil and gas held without limitation on liability (not through LP or LLC) is never passive, regardless of participation level. This exception recognizes the operating nature and liability exposure of working interests.
questions.tip: Oil/gas working interest (unlimited liability) = never passive. No participation required.

questions.question: A taxpayer sells a passive activity to their brother. What happens to suspended passive losses?

options.A: Fully released as with any sale
options.B: Remain suspended until the brother disposes to an unrelated party
options.C: Lost permanently
options.D: Partially released based on gain recognized

questions.explanation: Sales to related parties don't trigger full release of suspended losses. The losses remain suspended until the related party disposes of the activity to an unrelated person in a fully taxable transaction.
questions.tip: Related party sale: Suspended losses NOT released until related party sells to third party.

questions.question: A taxpayer dies with $100,000 of suspended passive losses and the activity has a $150,000 basis step-up. What happens to the suspended losses?

options.A: All $100,000 is deductible on the final return
options.B: $50,000 is deductible; $50,000 is lost
options.C: All $100,000 is lost due to the step-up
options.D: Losses transfer to the estate or beneficiary

questions.explanation: At death, suspended passive losses are deductible only to the extent they exceed the basis step-up. Here: Step-up of $150,000 exceeds the $100,000 suspended loss concept. Actually, losses allowed = suspended losses - step-up amount. If step-up > losses, remainder is lost.
questions.tip: Death: Suspended losses reduced by step-up. Excess losses allowed; absorbed losses lost.

questions.question: A non-REP taxpayer owns rental property and spends 800 hours on rental activities. Can the taxpayer treat rental losses as nonpassive?

options.B: No—must be a real estate professional for rental to be nonpassive
options.C: Yes—but only with the $25,000 allowance
options.D: No—rental activities are always passive for non-REPs

questions.explanation: For rentals, material participation alone doesn't convert passive to nonpassive. The taxpayer must qualify as a real estate professional (>750 hours AND >50% of services in real property trades) for rental losses to be nonpassive.
questions.tip: Rentals require REP status for nonpassive treatment. Material participation alone isn't enough.

questions.question: A taxpayer materially participated in an activity in 2022 but was passive in 2019-2021, accumulating $60,000 of suspended losses. In 2024, the activity generates $40,000 of income. How is the income and suspended loss treated?

options.A: All $40,000 is nonpassive; suspended losses remain suspended
options.B: Current income is nonpassive but releases $40,000 of suspended losses
options.C: $40,000 suspended loss offsets the income; $20,000 remains suspended
options.D: All income and losses are passive

questions.explanation: When material participation converts an activity from passive to nonpassive, current income is nonpassive but suspended losses from passive years can offset that income. $40,000 of suspended loss is released, leaving $20,000 still suspended.
questions.tip: Former passive activity: Current income is nonpassive; releases prior suspended losses.

questions.question: A taxpayer has $20,000 of passive losses from a publicly traded partnership (PTP) and $30,000 of passive income from a non-PTP passive activity. How are the losses used?

options.A: PTP losses offset the non-PTP income
options.B: PTP losses can only offset income from that same PTP
options.C: PTP losses offset portfolio income first
options.D: PTP losses are not subject to passive activity rules

questions.explanation: PTP losses can only offset income from the same PTP. They cannot offset other passive income, active income, or portfolio income. Each PTP is essentially its own 'basket' for loss limitation purposes.
questions.tip: PTP losses = same-PTP income only. Cannot cross-offset with other passive income.

questions.question: A taxpayer converts rental property to personal use. What happens to $80,000 of suspended passive losses?

options.A: Losses become deductible against any income
options.B: Losses are added to the property's basis
options.C: Losses remain suspended until sale

questions.explanation: Converting rental property to personal use is not a disposition that releases suspended losses. The losses remain suspended until the property is sold in a taxable transaction. Personal use doesn't trigger the release mechanism.
questions.tip: Conversion to personal use: Losses stay suspended. Only sale/taxable disposition releases them.

questions.question: A taxpayer has three passive activities: A has $30,000 loss, B has $20,000 loss, C has $25,000 income. Net passive loss is $25,000. If Activity A is sold and has $30,000 suspended loss, how much is released?
questions.explanation: Suspended losses are allocated among activities with losses based on their proportion. A's share: $30K / ($30K + $20K) × $25K net loss = 60% × $25K = $15,000 suspended from A. On disposition, only A's allocated suspended loss ($15,000) plus current loss ($30,000) is released.
questions.tip: Suspended loss allocation is proportional. Only the sold activity's allocated portion is released.

questions.question: A taxpayer sells passive activity business property, generating a Section 1231 gain. Is this gain passive or nonpassive?

options.B: Passive if the activity is passive
options.C: Portfolio income

questions.explanation: Section 1231 gain from disposition of property used in a passive activity retains its passive character. The character as 1231 gain (potentially capital gain) is separate from its passive/nonpassive classification.
questions.tip: Section 1231 gain: Passive character follows the activity. Tax character is separate issue.

questions.question: A high-income taxpayer has substantial passive losses from rental activities and wants to utilize them currently. Which strategy combination is most effective?

options.A: Increase participation hours in non-rental businesses
options.B: Qualify as real estate professional and elect single-activity treatment
options.C: Convert losses to at-risk carryforwards
options.D: Gift properties to release suspended losses

questions.explanation: REP status converts rental activities from per se passive to activities where material participation matters. Combined with single-activity election, 500+ total hours across all rentals enables full loss deduction. This is the most powerful strategy for rental investors.
questions.tip: REP + single activity election = most powerful strategy for high rental losses.
